awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating Biogeochemical Fluxes and Linkages To Climate Change With Multi-Scale Observations In The Drake Passage
awd_abstract_narration:
The Southern Ocean plays a key role in modulating the global carbon cycle, but the size and even the sign of the global ocean flux terms of the atmospheric burden of man-made CO2 are still uncertain. This is in part due to the lack of measurements in this remote region of the world ocean.  This project continues a multi-year time series of shipboard chemical measurements in the Drake Passage to detect changes in the ocean carbon cycle and to improve the understanding of mechanisms driving natural variability and long-term change in the Southern Ocean.

This project is a continuation of collection of upper ocean measurements of the underway surface partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2), using frequent ferry crossings of the Drake Passage by the RV/AS LMGould, the USAP supply ship. Overall, more than 200 transects over the past decade (since 2002) have now been accumulated of pCO2 profiles, along with discrete samples for other parameters of interest in studying the ocean carbonate system such as total CO2 (TCO2) values, isotopic (13C/12C and 14C/12C) ratios in surface TCO2.  The Drake Passage data are made readily available to the international science community and serve as both validation and constraints of remotely sensed observations and numerical coupled earth systems models.

por.por_cntn:
The Southern Ocean plays an outsized role in the global carbon cycle due in part to the unique connection between the surface and deep ocean in this region. Despite its importance, the spatial and temporal variability of key biogeochemical fluxes remain poorly known partly due to a lack of surface ocean data. The Drake Passage is a 780 km gap between the West Antarctic Peninsula (WAP) and the southern tip of South America that represents one of the best-sampled regions of the Southern Ocean for marine biogeochemistry thanks to underway sampling from the Antarctic Research Supply Vessel (ARSV) Laurence M. Gould. The focus of this study was both to characterize the spatial and temporal variability of marine biogeochemical parameters and improve understanding of mechanisms driving natural variability and long-term change of these parameters within the Southern Ocean. Several major contributions of this study during the grant period from September 1, 2016 to August 31, 2022 are described below.

 

More than 190,000 measurements of the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in surface water (pCO2surf) were made from the ARSV Gould over the grant period. Of these pCO2surf observations, over 52,000 were made during the cold season months of May through October when conditions in the Southern Ocean are harsh and pCO2surf observations within global databases are limited. pCO2surf observations made from the ARSV Gould were quality-controlled and submitted annually to the Surface Ocean CO2 Atlas (SOCAT). pCO2surf data were also included in the observation-based estimates of global air-sea CO2 flux published annually by the Global Carbon Project. Discrete surface water samples for macronutrients, total CO2 (TCO2), and the stable carbon isotopic composition of TCO2 (T13CO2) were collected on approximately one quarter of all Drake Passage transits over the grant period. These discrete measurements fully characterize the carbonate system and allow estimation of important carbon fluxes within the surface ocean.

 

An important aspect of ship-based pCO2surf sampling like that from the ARSV Gould is that these observations are irregularly distributed in space and time but are commonly used to make estimates of surface fluxes at the ocean basin scale on a monthly basis. In this case, it is important to investigate how representative a subregion like the Drake Passage is of the broader Southern Ocean especially given the unique physical ocean circulation of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) through this narrow constriction. Fay et al. (2018) analyzed the Drake Passage pCO2surf observations together with pCO2surf observations from other ocean regions within the Southern Ocean and found that the Drake Passage is representative of the broader region both in terms of seasonality and long-term trends. This study also compared the ship-based measurements to pCO2surf estimates based on pH measurements from floats deployed by the Southern Ocean Carbon and Climate Observations and Modeling (SOCCOM) project.

 

The WAP region is located within the marginal sea ice zone just south of the Drake Passage and is one of the most rapidly changing marine ecosystems on Earth. pCO2surf observations from the ARSV Gould along the WAP now span nearly two decades and are made throughout the year allowing characterization of both seasonal and long-term variability. Brown et al. (2019) used these observations together discrete water samples collected during the annual Palmer Long-Term Ecologcial Research (LTER) cruise to study long-term change in air-sea CO2 flux and mechanisms driving this change. This analysis found a fivefold increase in CO2 uptake in summer over the past 25 years linked to dramatic changes in mixed layer depth, biological production and species composition of phytoplankton blooms. This study also found a strong north-south gradient in both CO2 uptake and biological production with the most profound change observed in the southern LTER grid. Improved understanding of the mechanisms driving CO2 uptake may help predict future change in the marginal sea ice zone surrounding Antarctica.
